title: 107_s930
content:
The "Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001" includes sections on short title, definitions, fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, park surcharge, use of bond proceeds, report, and regulations. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Fundraising organization - entity authorized to act as a fundraising organization under section 3(a).
Memorandum of agreement - agreement entered into by the Secretary under section 3(a) containing specified terms.
Park - Grand Canyon National Park.
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary may enter into a memorandum of agreement with an entity to act as an authorized fundraising organization for the benefit of the Grand Canyon National Park. The fundraising organization shall issue taxable bonds in return for the surcharge collected for the Park. It must comply with professional standards and be subject to an audit by the Secretary. The United States shall not be liable for the bonds. The United States is not liable for bonds issued by the fundraising organization, as stated in the agreement with the Secretary. SEC. 4. MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, bond maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, project funding at the Park, and procedures for agreement modifications. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, bond maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, project funding at the Park, and procedures for modifications of the agreement with the consent of both parties based on changes in circumstances, including modifications relating to project priorities. SEC. 5. PARK SURCHARGE OR SET-ASIDE. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts, such as the recreational fee demonstration program or the national park passport program. The total amount charged or set aside may not exceed $2 for each individual charged an entrance fee, and the funds must be used by the fundraising organization. The funds collected may be used by the fundraising organization to amortize the bond issue, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations such as compliance with laws governing the National Park System and the Park's general management plan. No bond proceeds can be used for administration expenses. The bond proceeds cannot be used for administrative expenses, but interest earned on the proceeds can be used for reserve requirements and reasonable administrative expenses related to managing and selling the bonds. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of regulations being issued regarding the bond program at the Park, including a review and recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park System units. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
